parts.text: What does an alpha particle consist of?
markScheme: Answer: B - An alpha particle consists of 2 protons and 2 neutrons

parts.text: What is a beta particle?
markScheme: Answer: A - A beta particle is an electron emitted from the nucleus

parts.text: Which is a man-made source of background radiation?
markScheme: Answer: B - Nuclear accidents are a man-made source of background radiation

parts.text: Which two sources are natural sources of background radiation?
markScheme: 1 mark: Cosmic rays
1 mark: Radon gas

parts.text: Which sources of background radiation are natural and which are man-made?
markScheme: 1 mark: Cosmic rays — Natural
1 mark: Medical X-rays — Man-made
1 mark: Nuclear accidents — Man-made
1 mark: Radon gas — Natural

parts.text: A GM tube recorded 16, 21 and 18 counts in 1 minute on 3 separate occasions when no radioactive source was present. What is the most likely reason for the readings being different each time?
options: Radioactive decay is a random process
The air pressure in the laboratory increased
The background radiation increased during the day
The temperature in the laboratory decreased
markScheme: Answer: A - Radioactive decay is a random process, so background readings vary

parts.text: A radioactive source is stored in a box. Why does storing it in a lead-lined box reduce the risk to people nearby?
options: The lead lining absorbs the emitted radiation
The lead lining reflects the emitted radiation
The lead lining transmits the emitted radiation
markScheme: Answer: A - Lead absorbs the emitted radiation, reducing exposure

parts.text: A teacher measured a background count of 18 counts per minute. They then placed a radioactive source near the GM tube and the counter recorded 159 counts in 1 minute. How should the teacher calculate the count rate from the source alone?
markScheme: Answer: D - Subtract the background count from 159 to get the count from the source alone

parts.text: What is the activity of a radioactive source after one half-life?
options: A quarter of the original activity
markScheme: Answer: B - After one half-life the activity is half of the original activity

parts.text: What does 'half-life' mean?
options: Half the time taken for all nuclei to decay
The time taken for half the nuclei to decay
The time taken for one nucleus to split in half
markScheme: Answer: B - Half-life is the time taken for half the nuclei to decay

parts.text: How does the activity of a radioactive source affect the risk of harm to a person nearby?
options: The smaller the activity, the greater the risk
The activity does not affect the risk
The greater the activity, the greater the risk
markScheme: Answer: C - The greater the activity, the greater the risk of harm

parts.text: Carbon-12 and carbon-14 are both isotopes of carbon. Complete the sentences using words from the box.
segments: The nucleus of a carbon-12 atom and the nucleus of a carbon-14 atom have the same number of
. The nucleus of a carbon-12 atom and the nucleus of a carbon-14 atom have a different number of
markScheme: 1 mark: protons
1 mark: neutrons

parts.text: Table 1 shows the half-lives of some carbon isotopes. Which isotope is the least stable?
markScheme: Answer: D - Carbon-18 has the shortest half-life (0.09 s) so it is the least stable

parts.text: Alpha, beta and gamma radiation penetrate different materials. The experiment takes place in a vacuum. Three different materials are used: a sheet of paper, a 0.5 cm thick sheet of aluminium, and a 10 cm block of lead. For each type of radiation, is most of the radiation stopped by the sheet of paper?
markScheme: 1 mark: Alpha — Yes (stopped by paper)
1 mark: Beta — No (passes through paper)
1 mark: Gamma — No (passes through paper)

parts.text: A krypton (Kr) nucleus decays into a rubidium (Rb) nucleus by emitting a beta particle. An alpha particle is the same as a helium nucleus. How does this show that the decay emits a beta particle rather than an alpha particle?
options: The mass number stays the same
markScheme: Answer: A - In beta decay the mass number stays the same; in alpha decay it would decrease by 4

parts.text: A teacher measured the count rate from four radioactive rocks with different materials placed between the source and the detector. The results are shown in Table 1. Which rock emitted only alpha radiation?
markScheme: Answer: C - Rock C's count dropped to background level after paper was placed, indicating only alpha radiation

tables.caption: Count rates from radioactive rocks with different absorbers

parts.text: Give a reason for your answer to part (a).
markScheme: 1 mark: Alpha radiation is stopped by (one sheet of) **paper**, so the count dropped to background level after paper was placed between source and detector

parts.text: Which rock emitted only beta radiation?
markScheme: Answer: A - Rock A's count was not stopped by paper but dropped to background level after aluminium was placed

parts.text: Give a reason for your answer to part (c).
markScheme: 1 mark: Beta radiation is stopped by (a thick) **aluminium** sheet, so the count dropped to background after aluminium was placed

parts.text: Which precaution would prevent contamination by radioactive rocks?
options: Handling the rocks with clean hands
markScheme: Answer: C - Wearing protective gloves prevents radioactive material from contaminating the skin

parts.text: Why are workers required to walk across a sticky floor before leaving a nuclear power station?
options: To remove alpha particles from their shoes
To remove gamma radiation from their shoes
To remove radioactive dust from their shoes
markScheme: Answer: C - The sticky floor removes radioactive dust (contamination) from shoes

parts.text: An alpha particle is the same as the nucleus of a helium atom. How is an alpha particle different from a helium atom?
markScheme: 1 mark: Has no **electrons** (or: alpha has a positive charge / helium atom has no overall charge)

parts.text: The average background radiation dose per year in the UK is 2.0 millisieverts. A dental X-ray gives a dose of 0.005 millisieverts. Calculate how many dental X-rays would give the same dose as the average background radiation per year.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $\frac{2.0}{0.005}$
1 mark: Final answer: **400**

parts.text: An aeroplane pilot receives 0.072 mSv per day. A nuclear power station worker receives 0.00050 mSv per day. Calculate the number of days a nuclear power station worker must work to receive the same dose as a pilot in one day.
equations: $\text{number of days} = \frac{\text{pilot dose per day}}{\text{worker dose per day}}$
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $\frac{0.072}{0.00050}$
1 mark: Final answer: **144 days**

parts.text: Exposure to radon gas can cause lung cancer. A study compared the risk of getting lung cancer for smokers and non-smokers at different levels of radon exposure. Table 1 shows the results. Using information from Table 1, what conclusions can be made about exposure to radon gas and the risk of getting lung cancer?
markScheme: 1 mark: **Increased** levels of exposure increases the risk of developing cancer
1 mark: **Smoking** increases the harmful effect of radon

tables.caption: Risk of lung cancer at different radon exposure levels

parts.text: Suggest two reasons why a person may receive a higher than average dose of radiation from background sources.
markScheme: 1 mark: Any valid reason, e.g. frequent **flying** / living at **altitude**
1 mark: Any second valid reason, e.g. living in areas with high **radon** concentrations / having more **X-rays** than average

parts.text: A smoke detector contains americium-241 which emits alpha particles. Americium-241 has a half-life of 432 years. Which statement gives a reason why the americium-241 in the smoke detector will not need replacing?
options: The alpha particles have a low energy
People replace smoke detectors every few years
markScheme: Answer: C - Americium-241 has a long half-life so its activity barely changes over many years

parts.text: Why do people need to know that a smoke detector contains a radioactive material?
markScheme: 1 mark: Alpha particles / radiation is **harmful** (e.g. can cause cancer), so people can dispose of it safely or make an informed choice

parts.text: Complete the sentence about mass number using words from the box.
segments: The mass number is the total number of
markScheme: 1 mark: protons
1 mark: neutrons

parts.text: Radon-222 has a mass number of 222 and an atomic number of 86. How many protons are in an atom of radon-222?
When radon-222 emits an alpha particle, it changes to polonium-218. An alpha particle consists of 2 protons and 2 neutrons. How is the nucleus of polonium-218 different from the nucleus of radon-222?
acceptedAnswers: two fewer protons and two fewer neutrons
markScheme: 1 mark: Two fewer **protons** and two fewer **neutrons** (or: 84 protons and 134 neutrons)

parts.text: What is gamma radiation?
markScheme: 1 mark: **Electromagnetic** wave/radiation

parts.text: Food can be treated with gamma radiation to kill bacteria. Why must a source that emits gamma radiation be used rather than alpha or beta?
markScheme: 1 mark: Gamma can **penetrate** the crate/box/packaging

parts.text: A suitable source of gamma radiation is caesium-137. Complete the sentence using a word from the box.
segments: An atom of caesium-137 has two more
markScheme: 1 mark: neutrons

parts.text: The food treatment area has thick concrete walls. How do the concrete walls reduce the radiation hazard to workers outside the area?
markScheme: 1 mark: Concrete **absorbs** the gamma radiation

parts.text: A teacher passed radiation from a source through an electric field. Figure 1 shows the path the radiation took through the electric field. The radiation curved towards the positive plate. What type of radiation was being emitted?
parts.explanationPrompt: Explain the reason for your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct answer: **Beta**
1 mark: Beta is **negatively** charged
1 mark: So is **attracted** to the positive plate (or repelled by the negative plate)

parts.text: Which one of the following questions cannot be answered by scientific study?
options: Where does background radiation come from?
What is meant by the half-life of a radioactive source?
Should radioactive waste be dumped in the oceans?
markScheme: Answer: C - Whether radioactive waste should be dumped is an ethical/social question, not a scientific one

parts.text: A teacher used a Geiger-Muller tube and counter to measure the number of counts in 60 seconds for a radioactive rock. The counter recorded 819 counts in 60 seconds. The background radiation count rate was 0.30 counts per second. Calculate the corrected count rate for the rock in counts per second.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct calculation of count rate: $\frac{819}{60} = 13.65$ counts per second
1 mark: Correct subtraction of background: $13.65 - 0.30$
1 mark: Final answer: **13.35** counts per second

parts.text: Bananas are a source of background radiation. Some people think that the unit of radiation dose should be changed from sieverts to Banana Equivalent Dose. Suggest one reason why the Banana Equivalent Dose may help the public be more aware of radiation risks.
markScheme: 1 mark: People can **compare** a radiation dose to something familiar (eating **bananas**), making it easier to understand the risk

parts.text: Match each term to the correct example.
rightItems: Exposure to a beam of gamma rays
Exposure to ultraviolet radiation from the Sun
Accidental transfer of plutonium onto a human body
markScheme: 1 mark: Radioactive contamination --> Accidental transfer of plutonium onto a human body
1 mark: Nuclear irradiation --> Exposure to a beam of gamma rays

parts.text: A man-made source of background radiation is radiotherapy. Which of the following is also a man-made source of background radiation?
markScheme: Answer: B - Radiotherapy is a man-made source of background radiation

parts.text: The nuclear equation below represents the decay of plutonium-239. Figure 1 shows the equation. How does the nuclear equation show that alpha radiation is emitted when plutonium-239 decays?
options: An alpha particle has a mass number of 235
An alpha particle is the same as a helium nucleus
markScheme: Answer: C - An alpha particle is the same as a helium nucleus (2 protons, 2 neutrons)

parts.text: Figure 2 shows a graph of how the activity of a sample of plutonium-239 varies with time. How much time will it take for the activity of the sample to fall to half of its initial activity?
markScheme: 1 mark: **24 000** years (accept answers between 24 000 and 24 500 years)

parts.text: The radioactive waste from a nuclear power station is buried underground. People are warned to stay away from places where radioactive waste is buried. Suggest one risk of going near the place where radioactive waste is buried.
markScheme: 1 mark: **Irradiation** / exposure to radiation that could cause **cancer** / genetic damage / mutations / radiation sickness

parts.text: 1 kg of granite has an activity of 1250 Bq. A kitchen worktop has a mass of 180 kg. Calculate the activity of the worktop.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $1250 \times 180$
1 mark: Final answer: **225 000 Bq**

parts.text: The average radiation dose from the granite worktop is 0.003 millisieverts per day. The lowest dose with evidence of causing cancer is 100 millisieverts. Explain why the householder should not be concerned about their yearly radiation dose from the granite worktop. (1 year = 365 days)
markScheme: 1 mark: Yearly dose = $0.003 \times 365$ = **1.095 mSv**
1 mark: Which is much less than **100 mSv** (the lowest dose with evidence of causing cancer)

questions.title: Uranium decay and age of the Earth
questions.subject: physics

parts.text: Uranium-238 decays by emitting radiation and changing into thorium-234. What type of radiation is emitted?
markScheme: Answer: A - The mass number decreases by 4 and the atomic number by 2, indicating alpha emission

parts.text: From which part of a uranium-238 atom is the radiation emitted?
markScheme: 1 mark: The (unstable) **nucleus**

parts.text: Uranium-235 is another isotope of uranium. How is an atom of uranium-235 similar to an atom of uranium-238?
acceptedAnswers: they have the same number of protons
markScheme: 1 mark: Same number of **protons** (or same atomic number, or both have 92 protons)

parts.text: Uranium-238 has a half-life of 4500 million years. When the Earth was formed, there was twice as much uranium-238 as there is now. What is the age of the Earth?
markScheme: 1 mark: **4500 million years**

parts.text: What is the mass number of an atom?
acceptedAnswers: total number of protons and neutrons
total number of protons plus neutrons
markScheme: 1 mark: Total number of **protons** plus **neutrons** (or number of nucleons)

parts.text: Beta decay does not cause the mass number of an atom to change. Explain why not.
markScheme: 1 mark: The number of **neutrons** decreases by one
1 mark: The number of **protons** increases by one (a neutron changes into a proton)

parts.text: It is impossible for the alpha decay of bismuth-212 to produce the same element as the beta decay of bismuth-212. Explain why.
markScheme: 1 mark: The number of **protons** determines the element (or atomic number)
1 mark: Alpha and beta decay produce **different changes** to the number of protons

parts.text: Explain why contamination of the inside of the human body by a radioactive material that emits alpha radiation is highly dangerous.
markScheme: 1 mark: Alpha radiation is highly **ionising**
1 mark: Causing increased risk of **cancer** / organ failure / radiation sickness / mutation of DNA
1 mark: The radioactive material remains inside the body (all alpha radiation is **absorbed** by the body)

parts.text: A sample of polonium-210 was left for 414 days. After this time it had a mass of $1.45 \times 10^{-4}$ g. The half-life of polonium-210 is 138 days. Calculate the initial mass of the sample.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $\frac{414}{138} = 3$ half-lives
1 mark: Correct rearrangement: $1.45 \times 10^{-4} \times 2 \times 2 \times 2$
1 mark: Final answer: **$1.16 \times 10^{-3}$ g** (or 0.00116 g)

parts.text: A teacher recorded three background radiation readings: 17, 21 and 19 counts per minute. Calculate the mean value of the background radiation.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $\frac{17 + 21 + 19}{3}$
1 mark: Final answer: **19** counts per minute

parts.text: The teacher put a powerful magnet between the radioactive source and the GM tube. The count rate stayed the same. What type of radiation was being emitted?
markScheme: Answer: C - Gamma radiation has no charge so is not deflected by a magnetic field

parts.text: Explain the reason for your answer to part (b) about why this type of radiation is not affected by the magnetic field.
markScheme: 1 mark: **Gamma** has no charge (or gamma is an electromagnetic wave)
1 mark: So gamma is not **deflected** / affected by a magnetic field

parts.text: A study compared the risk of getting lung cancer for cigarette smokers and non-smokers at different levels of radon exposure. People that have had no exposure to radon gas were included in the study. Why were they included?
markScheme: 1 mark: To act as a **control** / to compare the effect of exposure with **no exposure**

parts.text: The 'linear no-threshold' (LNT) model and the 'radiation hormesis' model suggest different links between the risk of developing cancer and exposure to low levels of radiation. Figure 1 shows graphs for both models. Describe how the link between the risk of developing cancer and exposure to low levels of radiation suggested by each model is different.
markScheme: 1 mark: LNT model: risk **increases** (in proportion) with increasing radiation dose
1 mark: Radiation hormesis: **low** radiation doses **reduce** the risk of cancer

parts.text: Scientists have conducted experiments in which mice have been exposed to different levels of radiation. Discuss whether it is ethical to use animals in scientific experiments.
markScheme: 1 mark: Any valid point against, e.g. animals have no **choice** and so should not be used / should not make animals **suffer**
1 mark: Any valid point for, e.g. better to experiment on **animals** than humans / experiments may lead to health **improvements** or cures for humans

parts.text: A conveyor belt is used to move food past a radioactive source that emits gamma radiation. Suggest one way that the dose of radiation received by the food could be increased, other than by changing the radioactive source.
markScheme: 1 mark: **Slow down** the conveyor belt (or move the food closer to the source / food does more than one circuit)

parts.text: What evidence could a food scientist produce to show that food treated with radiation is safe to eat?
markScheme: 1 mark: Test the food on humans or animals / feed it to volunteers
1 mark: Show no measured **ill effects** / monitor their health / compare radiation levels in treated and untreated food

parts.text: A sign is displayed on food treated with radiation. Why is it important for people to know which foods have been treated with radiation?
markScheme: 1 mark: So people can make their own **decision** / **choice** about eating or not eating treated food

parts.text: A teacher measured count rate at different distances from a radioactive source. At distances of 1.6 m, 1.8 m and 2.0 m, the count rate was 18 counts per minute and the corrected count rate was 0. What is the value of the background count rate?
markScheme: 1 mark: **18** counts per minute

parts.text: The corrected count rate is the count rate after subtracting the background count rate. What information does the corrected count rate give?
acceptedAnswers: the count rate from the source alone
the count rate due to the source alone
count rate from just the source
markScheme: 1 mark: The count rate due to the **source** alone (without background radiation)

parts.text: Table 1 shows the results. At 1.6 m the corrected count rate is 0, but the source is not an alpha emitter. How can you tell from the data that the source is not an alpha emitter?
markScheme: 1 mark: Alpha radiation would not travel as far as 0.4 m (the source was detected at distances up to 1.4 m, which is too far for **alpha** radiation)

tables.caption: Count rate at different distances from a radioactive source
